t: Again*p I looked and saw all the oppression that was taking place under the sun: I*pn saw the tears of the oppressed— and*ld they have no comforter; power*ln was on the side of their oppressors— and*ld they have no comforter.
And*ln I declared that the dead, who*ld had already died, are*ln happier than the living, who*ld are still alive.
But*ln better than both is*ld the one who has never been born, who*ln has not seen the evil that*ld is done under the sun.
And*p I saw that all toil and all achievement spring from one person’s envy of another. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
Fools*pn fold their hands and*ld ruin themselves.
Better*ln one handful with tranquillity than*ld two handfuls with toil and*ld chasing after the wind.
Again*p I saw something meaningless under the sun:

There*pn was a man all alone; he*ld had neither son nor brother. There*ln was no end to his toil, yet*ld his eyes were not content with his wealth. “For*ln whom am I toiling,” he asked, “and*ld why am I depriving myself of enjoyment?” This*ln too is meaningless— a*ld miserable business!
Two*pn are better than one, because*ld they have a good return for their labor:
If*ln either of them falls down, one*ld can help the other up. But*ln pity anyone who falls and*ld has no one to help them up.
Also,*ln if two lie down together, they will keep warm. But*ld how can one keep warm alone?
Though*ln one may be overpowered, two*ld can defend themselves. A*ln cord of three strands is not quickly broken.
Better*p a poor but wise youth than an old but foolish king who no longer knows how to heed a warning.
The youth may have come from prison to the kingship, or he may have been born in poverty within his kingdom.
I saw that all who lived and walked under the sun followed the youth, the king’s successor.
There was no end to all the people who were before them. But those who came later were not pleased with the successor. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
